image.altText: Christine Finnegan smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: The Tasmania JackJumpers entered the National Basketball League three years ago and won their first title on Sunday. The club's chief executive, Christine Finnegan, says she wants to work with Tasmania's start-up AFL club, the Tasmania Devils, and the two clubs can "defend the island" together.

title.children: JackJumpers and Devils can 'defend the island' together, says basketball team head

image.altText: Two pictures of two separate men, both wearing suits outside court.

props.synopsis: Taylor Auerbach is questioned about a night in Sydney when he dined with Bruce Lehrmann at a Sydney restaurant for the purpose of securing an exclusive interview.

title.children: 'Bruce was on the warpath': Former Seven producer says network paid for sex workers and drugs for Bruce Lehrmann

image.altText: A landscape photo of a rainbow shining over a dry grassy paddock with bushland in the distance in golden light.

props.synopsis: It's been the driest February and March on record for King Island and parts of south-east Tasmania. Some areas have received welcome April rain, but farmers elsewhere are struggling.

title.children: Farmers on Tasmania's usually green King Island are struggling with drought conditions

image.altText: Joe Biden sits in front of Israeli and American flags. He is speaking.

props.synopsis: US President Joe Biden and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speak, days after an IDF strike killed aid workers — including an Australian — delivering food in Gaza.

title.children: 'Immediate ceasefire is essential': Biden tells Israel support for Gaza war depends on new steps to protect civilians

image.altText: Satellite image of three cars on coastal road.

props.synopsis: A group of international experts analysed images and geolocations of wreckages to offer their views on the deadly Gaza aid convoy strike, which Israel claims was "unintentional", blaming it on "misidentification".

title.children: Israel says deadly Gaza aid convoy strike was a 'grave mistake', but experts say the images tell a different story

image.altText: Ryan Gury at a drone racing event

props.synopsis: A small community of hobby drone racers, chasing a need for speed, unintentionally made a "terrifyingly powerful" weapon that has changed the world.

title.children: Ryan was the 'da Vinci' of drone building. He's now making weapons as his inventions transform war

image.altText: A close up of two men. One wears glasses and a dark suit and the other with grey hair wearing a white shirt.

props.synopsis: A years-long stand-off between two men over the future of Disney has finally come to an end. This is what we know about how chief executive Bob Iger vanquished investor Nelson Peltz.

title.children: Disney's astonishingly well-paid CEO has vanquished his rival. But a succession drama still looms

image.altText: A woman sits with her head in her hands at a table surrounded by bills

props.synopsis: The Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services will look at existing laws, the possible role of banks, and public awareness of what is considered a more hidden form of family and domestic violence.

title.children: 'I'm still in survival mode': Lily was destroyed by economic abuse, and says her bank could have done more

props.synopsis: The Coalition have clearly decided they are backing the Israeli government all the way. But this has left them seemingly unable to condemn actions that led to the death of an Australian aid worker.

title.children: Angus Taylor ties himself in knots over an airstrike as the Coalition tethers itself to Israel

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory senator says youth crime in the Alice and other parts of NT has risen due to the circumstances children are being brought up in.

title.children: Price concerned NT could become a 'lockdown territory' due to wave of youth crime

image.altText: A police officer talks to a kid in Alice Springs during the evening.

props.synopsis: For many residents, the two-youth curfew in Alice Springs has transformed the Central Australian town. But with less than a week to go until the temporary restrictions end, some are concerned about a return to the violence that sparked the curfew in the first place.

title.children: 'People feel safe': How Alice Springs has gone from 'hectic' to 'quiet' during the youth curfew

image.altText: A crowd of people fill of young kids and adults wearing white helmets

props.synopsis: Western Australian Labor MP Tania Lawrence, and Brisbane-native Peter Dunstan were in Taiwan when an earthquake hit. They say the shaking was aggressive and the strongest ever felt.

title.children: Australians in Taiwan during the earthquake recount moments of 'violent' shaking and noise

image.altText: Linda Baumann and her grandson Connor sit next to each other on a park bench. They're both smiling and happy.

props.synopsis: RSV vaccines are available for Australians for the first time this winter, and grandparents like Linda Baumann can't wait to get their jab.

title.children: RSV vaccines are here in time for winter flu season – but not everyone is eligible

image.altText: Afsoun Rastegari wearing large headphones and looking into the camera while waiting at a train station.

props.synopsis: Employers are stepping up their game to entice staff back into the office. But, not all perks are created equal, with some — like offering a longer holiday — proving more effective than others.

title.children: Free lunch, golf driving range, kombucha on tap – what does it take to get workers back in the office?

image.altText: Collage photo of Willie Nelson, Paul McCartney, Miley Cyrus, Beyonce, Pharrell Williams, Nile Rodgers and Dolly Parton

props.synopsis: The guest list for Beyoncé's new album is a mixture of country heroes, emerging hip hop stars, and some of her closest and most famous regular collaborators.

title.children: Not just Miley and Dolly: The musical big guns who collaborated on Beyoncé's Cowboy Carter

image.altText: A man wearing a black shirt and glasses.

props.synopsis: Last month, the alleged cult leader and convicted paedophile, William "Little Pebble" Kamm, was arrested with his partner over the alleged grooming of a child. He's now on track to be released on bail.

title.children: Religious leader and convicted paedophile 'Little Pebble' accused of grooming child set for bail release

image.altText: Australian women's cricket captain Alyssa Healy grins widely at her teammate after the team takes a wicket in a T20I.

props.synopsis: Australia beats Bangladesh by 77 runs in the third T20 International, completing a clean sweep of the series on their women's cricket tour.

title.children: Australia's women cricketers complete Bangladesh sweep in Dhaka

image.altText: a bald man sit in front of a vessel

props.synopsis: Sam McLennan has spent a year building a raft from materials found either in the sea or washed ashore. His plan to sail it from Hobart to Sydney has been thwarted by safety concerns, but he's hopeful he'll be able to set sail soon.

title.children: A plan to sail a raft built of rubbish from Hobart to Sydney has been put on hold

image.altText: Electoral commission campaign, woman grins and signals number '7'. Text reads '7 or more to make your vote count'

props.synopsis: This year's state election returned a near-record rise in the number of votes that couldn't be counted, with some voters when numbering from one to seven on the ballot doubling or omitting a six or doubling or omitting a seven.

title.children: Tasmanian voters confused when numbering from 1 to 7, with double ups of 6 in state election count

image.altText: Aly leans over a desk as she speaks on the lower house floor.

props.synopsis: The prime minister says it "isn't good enough" for Israel to dismiss as an accident an air strike that killed seven aid workers, including one Australian, as one of his frontbenchers claims Israel is flouting the rules of war.

title.children: Frontbencher says Israel flouting rules of war, as government demands accountability on killed aid workers

image.altText: A soldier dressed in army uniform wears a mask and helmet and holds a gun in front of a fence.

props.synopsis: Groups opposing the military junta claim they launched a successful mass drone attack on the country's capital but the army insists there were no casualties.

title.children: Myanmar resistance groups launch rare drone attack on capital Naypyitaw

image.altText: A group of Melbourne AFL defenders walk on the ground, as one sends a thumbs-up signal.

props.synopsis: Melbourne slog out a 15-point win over Adelaide in the opening match of Gather Round, leaving the Crows in dire straits and winless after four games.

title.children: Demons make it four in a row as winless Crows' despair deepens in Gather Round opener

image.altText: A dejected Brisbane Broncos player sits between teammates on the bench with the hood up on his jacket, looking at the game.

props.synopsis: Melbourne Storm have gone top of the ladder with a 34-32 win at home over the Brisbane Broncos — but the visitors' season goes from bad to worse with an injury to playmaker Adam Reynolds.

title.children: Adam Reynolds injured as Broncos fall to Storm in game of the season

image.altText: A man in a suit holds up his hand in front of a red backdrop

props.synopsis: Breaking from the usual reluctance to tie Australia's deal to acquire nuclear-powered submarines to tensions with China, America's second most-powerful diplomat suggests AUKUS subs could be deployed in any war over Taiwan.

title.children: US official says Australia's AUKUS submarines could be used to fight China in war over Taiwan

image.altText: An illustration of Edward Henty and other settlers with large barrels, guns and livestock on a beach.

props.synopsis: Hearings at Victoria's Yoorrook Justice Commission have shone a light on the violence that underpinned the state's colonisation in the 1830s, truths the commission hopes will pave the way to a more mature understanding of Victoria's past and present.

title.children: Driven by 'land hunger', this man started Victoria's colonisation in 1834. It quickly became a 'disaster'

image.altText: A crocodile trapped in a crocodile trap

props.synopsis: Whoever released a trapped saltwater crocodile back into a popular Kimberley lake at the end of the Easter long weekend jeopardised the safety of the community, authorities have said.

title.children: Crocodile trap 'tampered with' as authorities condemn release of 2-metre reptile into popular Kimberley lake

image.altText: a blonde woman wearing all black sitting at a desk with bookshelves filled with books and plants behind her

props.synopsis: Lauren has a unique problem. Her attic is producing an endless supply of husbands. That's the set-up of a new novel called The Husbands by Australian author Holly Gramazio, who says she wouldn't have picked her own husband if she'd encountered him online.

title.children: Author of The Husbands wouldn't have chosen hers if she'd seen his dating profile — which proves her point

image.altText: Barge cranes are shown near the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge on the Patapsco River.

props.synopsis: The crane has taken many roles over the decades but it's most notable operation until last week was a secret mission to retrieve a sunken Soviet submarine.

title.children: The crane used to haul away the Francis Scott Key bridge had a secret role in the Cold War

image.altText: A glass mug of cranberry juice with cranberries scattered around it. The outstretched palm of a hand also holds cranberries.

props.synopsis: You may have been told by a family member or a friend to drink cranberry juice if you've ever found yourself suffering with the uncomfortable symptoms of a UTI. But, does it work?

title.children: Is cranberry juice an effective treatment option for urinary tract infections?

image.altText: A picture of Balmoral Castle exterior with some colourful gardens

props.synopsis: The royal residences were open to tourists before, but now visitors will be able to see even more of the historical locations and take private tours with special guides.

title.children: Balmoral Castle and Buckingham Palace set to open off-limits rooms for 'exclusive tours'

image.altText: A close up of a woman holding a fringe bag wearing an orange shawl and pants.

props.synopsis: Australians in Bali for holidays have been left confused by a new $15 tourism tax and efforts by police to enforce payment.

title.children: Fed up with badly behaved tourists and obnoxious influencers, Bali has a new tax and a new list of rules

image.altText: A smiling Indian woman hair tied, looped over shoulder, red and white printed shirt, glasses, red lipstick, smiles at camera.

props.synopsis: Women's health specialists say gender bias in rebates for medical procedures is costing women more money and disincentivising women's health practitioners.

title.children: Gender inequity 'baked into the system' for Medicare rebates, doctors' group says

image.altText: A close up of a smiling Juan Vicente Pérez Mora surrounded by people in facemasks.

props.synopsis: Juan Vicente Pérez Mora, who was a month away from his 115th birthday, is history's fourth oldest male whose age has been officially ratified.

title.children: The world's oldest living man, who attributes health to daily nip of liquor, dies aged 114

image.altText: A parfait sits on black plate with spoon and wine glass nearby.

props.synopsis: The first product from an Australian cell-cultured meat company has today gone on sale in Singapore, where the Japanese quail cell parfait can be found in high-end restaurants.

title.children: Australian lab-grown meat with 'perfect' texture hits the shelves in Singapore

image.altText: A woman in a blue dress sitting in a wheelchair in her home.

props.synopsis: Qantas has been slammed over its treatment of a woman with disability who was trying to get from Perth to Canberra for a work trip.

title.children: 'Unacceptable and appalling': Qantas charged Anwen $6.4k for business seats because economy wasn't accessible
